instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message:
Hi, i have a macbook pro here, my client trying to solve a wifi problem, burn the lvds conector and the lvds flex .. i reeplace thad but after replace, to remove the excess of flux i put the board in the ultrasonic and before that.. no turns on anymore. in any moment before the ultrasonic shows a green light and orange.. but in a moment taking a measures accidentaly touch the pin 1 of the <CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR> and pin 1 of the <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> and the light is gone. so.. there is my measures

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3,35v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12,23v
PPDCIN 18,71v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> 1,14v

i replace the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and have same result.. any sugestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message:
what cleaner do you have?
Rewind 3 years, i killed allot of chipsets in substandard cleaners. what ultrasonic cleaner do you have.
Maybe 2/10 repairs would go into the cleaner working and come out dead.
I mean fully dead, quater fan spin dead (due to bad PCH's)

In the case of MCP79's and 89's id get no S4/3
If this board isnt liquid related your cleaner/or fluid has probably killed the MCP, sounds silly but i spent allot of time messing with fluids and a cheap cleaner.
I used some pink stuff once and a working board came out of my crest with a bad PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message:
Have you had this issue before?
Are you 100% its non liquid damaged? In some cases bad but semi intact probe points will loose connection during the cleaning cycle

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message: im pretty sure this is not a liquid damage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message:
Okay, ACOK is 1.14V so how do you have a green light, It could be something to do with that.
Does it work in SMC bypass?
Thanks
Zac

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message: how can do a sms bypass? just for proof.. i dont have greenlight

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message:
You can google a SMC bypass, it bypasses certain function of SMC's
Its just holding the power button for 10 seconds before attaching a power source (such as a battery or charger)

anyway with ACOK low id suggest replacing the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message: ok, i will try replace <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> again.. see later and say u how im going

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message: You killed the SMC by shorting out 3V42 to something. This in most cases kills the MCP too. Toast I say.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message: You replace the SMC and the MCP89 will be dead as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message:
replace smc and see if you killed the rest of the shit,
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 12,23volt most times say SMC is dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after ultrasonic.
threads.message: Remove SMC then measure resistance to GND on the 3V42 rail and report the value here. I'm pretty sure this board will be fucked.
